utterances: Well, you know, I'll end on this.
I was blessed with being able to speak to the actual EMTs that - not to be graphic, but kind of scraped me up.
And it was - it brought a tear to my eye to be able to thank them in person.
So, that's that.
I wish you Godspeed, and I'll say farewell.
Chris, thanks for the call.
Thanks.
Thank you.
Let's go now to Hunter, Hunter from Flagstaff in Arizona.
Hello, gentlemen.
Go ahead, please.
Hi.
I didn't know what to expect when I came to look at CHIP, a $9 computer.
And I'd look at them and say, you know, let me tell you what's very important.
It's your family and it's your friends and it's your life.
And this project is going to come and go.
There's going to be 100 more right behind it.
But you get one ride on this merry-go-round.
And do you change your - obviously, your perspective has changed, and that's good, too.
But I wonder, did either of you have the impulse to say, you know, I'm going to change my name to Albert Schweitzer and minister to the poor?
I think it was - for me, it was a little more subtle.
When I'm thinking about making a decision, we do it.
I mean, my wife and I now, you know, we've been talking about this - let's do it.
You know, we - you realize how finite everything is and it really - we talk about the initial depression.
I did suffer from that.
And then I kind of snapped out of that and thought, man, you know, you're here and you have been blessed with the opportunity to go forward and live your life.
I'm, you know, I'm 50 now and I figure, you know, we got 30 more years of this and, you know, 25 if you're lucky, 10 if you're lucky.
And so we hustle up a little more than we once did.
Do you find yourself being more decisive, Tim Kreider?
More decisive?
Yeah.
Let's do it, sort of.
Oh, certainly not.
No.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
Hunter, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you, gentlemen.
We're talking with cartoonist Tim Kreider.
His comic strip is ""The Pain — When Will It End?"" He written an essay called ""Reprieve"" that was published in the New York Times' Happy Days Blog and got a lot of response to it.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's try Peter, Peter with us from Berkeley.
Hi, thanks.
Great topic.
I remember the exhilaration I felt after recovering from a broken, actually, shattered collar bone.
What happened, I was on a deck behind a vacation house with no environmental light.
And I fell off an eight - this eight-foot deck head first.
Oh.
And so it was terribly painful.
I didn't have any time to be exhilarated about my survival.
But it was in reflecting afterwards that I realized how close I came to being much, much worse.
And then after lying around on the floor at home, you know, for collar bone, they don't give you a cast or much of anything.
They'll just say, rest as best as you can.
Luckily, I did have meditation which helped me enormously.
But boy, when I get out and took my first few walks out around the block from my little studio apartment, that was when it hit me just how wonderful this life is.
I looked around and everybody was acting normal.
And I said, don't you see how great it is to be alive?
(Soundbite of laughter)
I was just thinking that every step was so great, every leaf, every ray of sunshine.
And unfortunately, that did wear off after awhile, but I would describe that as not taking life for granted.
And then if you could just get yourself in that frame of mind once in a while, and just remind yourself.
So it's - and another form of survival that I might bring up because it would be so topical for so many people right now is economic survival.
And I did survive quite a bit of setbacks where I got cheated three years in a row in different ways and it just compounded one after another after the other.
But, you know, all these years later, I survived.
I never went bankrupt, and my credit is cleaning up, you know?
And I - big corporations go bankrupt.
I did not, and it's really great.
Peter, thanks very much for the story.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
And here's an email from Joel in San Antonio.
About two years ago in Mexico City, I was driving through a pretty affluent neighborhood in the early afternoon.
At a stop sign, a man banged on my window and demanded I let him in.
I got out of the car with my arms raised, thinking this is a simple carjacking.
Another man came out of nowhere, shoved me in the backseat.
The next four hours were nightmarish.
I was coerced to go to ATMs throughout the city and empty out whatever accounts I could.
When I was only able to withdraw the equivalent of $400, one of the men cocked his revolver and pointed it at me, demanding more.
There would be certain death if I couldn't come up with more.
I just stood there, looked down on the concrete and braced myself for the bullet.
What happened next, I still have to come up with an explanation for.
He threw my keys at my face and both men ran off.
I've tried not to let it affect my everyday life, but it's a hard realization to have that you can die anytime, anywhere.
It definitely has made me appreciate the time I do have left on Earth.
It is one of the maddening perversities of human psychology that we only notice we're alive when we're reminded we're going to die.
Sort of the same way some of us only appreciate our girlfriends after they're exes.
And you've had time to contemplate that?
Yeah.

You know, hearing some of these stories, I feel that my own pretty stupid misadventures in commensurate to the kinds of real traumas and losses people have undergone - I mean, I didn't have to go through any kind of painful or lengthy rehabilitation.
I didn't lose anybody I loved.
You know, this will sound ridiculous, but in ways it's the best thing that could possibly have happened to me.
You know, I was sort of a typical depressed twenty-something, and it, you know, afterwards I was kind of like Ebenezer Scrooge after ghost number three.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I wonder, you said this was not a religious experience for you.
For some people, it is.
I wonder, how do you respond to them when they contact you?
Why don't you - why don't we open one of these boxes so you can see what the actual box process is?
This is Dave Rauchwerk, the CEO of Next Thing Co. that makes CHIP.
You know, oddly, I didn't hear from anybody who, you know, reproached me for not having been more thankful to God.
But I'm not a sort of person who would have imagined that God spared my life for some special purpose.

But even if I were prone to that kind of thinking - you know, the Oklahoma City bombing happened the day that I was in recuperative coma, so I'd like to think that that kind of ghastly coincidence would've quashed any such notion when I woke up.
I can't really imagine a plan that would've called for that but required me to survive.
You know, it was luck, or physics, whatever you want to call it.
But I am very conscious of being lucky.
A lot of people told me so after I woke up.
Thanks very much for being with us.
We're lucky today.
Thank you, sir.
Cartoonist Tim Kreider's comic strip is titled ""The Pain — When Will It End."" He's currently working on a third book of political cartoons.
And he joined us today from our bureau in New York.
In Egypt, a constitutional reform panel has recommended a more competitive presidential ballot and a two-term limit on future presidents.
The proposals will be put to a referendum later this year.
As life in Egypt slowly returns to normal, people in the country's vital tourism industry are counting their losses.
Economists say the country has lost more than a billion dollars in tourist revenue.
Among the hardest-hit cities is Luxor in upper Egypt, home to some of the world's most famous tombs and temples.
